events.description: Ricardo Lagos became the President of Chile after winning 51.3 percent of the vote in the presidential runoff held in January 2000.
supporting_quotes: Winning 51.3 percent of the vote, Lagos became the new President of Chile.

President
Ricardo Lagos
PPD
11 March 2000–11 March 2006

events.description: Confronted high unemployment, promised to manage budget deficit, interest rates, and inflation.
supporting_quotes: During the first year of his term in office, Lagos had to confront a high level of unemployment, generated by the political instability of the region, a process that began to revert at the end of 2003. He also promised to keep the budget deficit in check and interest rates and inflation low.
events.raw_llm_output:

```json
{
  "events": [
    {
      "organization": "Government of Chile",
      "role": "President",
      "location": "Chile",
      "start_date": "2001",
      "end_date": null,
      "description": "Confronted high unemployment, promised to manage budget deficit, interest rates, and inflation.",
      "supporting_quotes": ["During the first year of his term in office, Lagos had to confront a high level of unemployment, generated by the political instability of the region, a process that began to revert at the end of 2003. He also promised to keep the budget deficit in check and interest rates and inflation low."]
    },
    {
      "organization": "Government of Chile",
      "role": "President",
      "location": "Chile",
      "start_date": null,
      "end_date": null,
      "description": "Opened the doors of the Palacio de La Moneda to the public, a symbol of proximity with people.",
      "supporting_quotes": ["The policy of proximity with people was pronounced in the opening of the doors of the Palacio de La Moneda, that had remained closed since the 1973 coup d'état."]
    },
    {
      "organization": "Government of Chile",
      "role": "President",
      "location": "Chile",
      "start_date": "2001",
      "end_date": null,
      "description": "Signed a bill to abolish the death penalty for civilian crimes, setting maximum punishment at life imprisonment.",
      "supporting_quotes": ["On 3 April 2001, with a 63-37-4 vote, the Chamber of Deputies of Chile approved a bill to abolish the death penalty in Chile for civilian crimes and set the maximum punishment at life imprisonment. The law was set to go into effect as soon as then-President Lagos signed it, which he did weeks later."]
    },
    {
      "organization": "Government of Chile",
      "role": "President",
      "location": "Chile",
      "start_date": "2002",
      "end_date": null,
      "description": "Faced suspicions of political corruption due to the MOP-GATE case involving Minister Carlos Cruz and other civil employees.",
      "supporting_quotes": ["Beginning in 2002, Lagos' government had to face suspicions of political corruption due to the prosecution of one of his ministers, Carlos Cruz, and of other civil employees of the Public Works Ministry, in the denominated MOP-GATE case."]
    },
    {
      "organization": "Government of Chile",
      "role": "President",
      "location": "Chile",
      "start_date": null,
      "end_date": null,
      "description": "Acknowledged and addressed the issue of 'extra payments' to ministers and officials, leading to a legal reform increasing their pay.",
      "supporting_quotes": ["This irregularity was acknowledged by Lagos, who specified that the practice had also developed during the governments of Frei Ruiz-Tagle and Aylwin. The official position of the government consisted of not acknowledging the criminal nature of these practices and establishing a legal reform that increased the pay of ministers and undersecretaries of the government, a matter that was approved in its legislative proceeding."]
    }
  ]
}
```

```json
      "supporting_quotes": ["On 3 April 2001, with a 63-37-4 vote, the Chamber of Deputies of Chile approved a bill to abolish the death penalty in Chile for civilian crimes and set the maximum punishment at life imprisonment.     },
    {
      "organization": "Government of Chile",
      "role": "President",
      "location": "Chile",
      "start_date": "2002",
      "end_date": null,
      "description": "Faced suspicions of political corruption due to the MOP-GATE case involving Minister Carlos Cruz and other civil employees.",
      "supporting_quotes": ["Beginning in 2002, Lagos' government had to face suspicions of political corruption due to the prosecution of one of his ministers, Carlos Cruz, and of other civil employees of the Public Works Ministry, in the denominated MOP-GATE case."]
    },
    {
      "organization": "Government of Chile",
      "role": "President",
      "location": "Chile",
      "start_date": null,
      "end_date": null,
      "description": "Acknowledged and addressed the issue of 'extra payments' to ministers and officials, leading to a legal reform increasing their pay.",
      "supporting_quotes": ["This irregularity was acknowledged by Lagos, who specified that the practice had also developed during the governments of Frei Ruiz-Tagle and Aylwin.     }
```

events.description: Led the democratic transition after the defeat of Pinochet, established a Presidential Commission to investigate human rights violations during the dictatorship.
supporting_quotes: I remember that the Commander in Chief went to see me one day and said: ‘Mr. President, do you want to know the truth?’ ‘Yes, I want the truth.’

events.role: Leader of the opposition to Pinochet
events.description: Believed in the possibility of defeating Pinochet and worked to convince others to vote against the dictatorship.
supporting_quotes: I believed it was possible to defeat Pinochet. I had no doubt. The question was how we were going to make other people to believe that.
I had to be able to knock on the door of every house in Chile and say: ‘I invite [you] to say ‘no’ because one, two, three, four’.

events.description: Pursued free-trade agreements, improved health care and education, and addressed the crimes of General Augusto Pinochet’s military regime.
supporting_quotes: Ricardo Lagos served as president of Chile from 2000 to 2006. While in office Lagos was known for pursuing free-trade agreements, improving health care and education, and addressing the crimes of General Augusto Pinochet’s military regime.

events.description: Designated by President Salvador Allende but never took office.
supporting_quotes: Well, I was designated by Allende to be ambassador in Moscow. I never reached Moscow.

events.description: Served during the transition from Pinochet's authoritarian regime to democracy, focusing on maintaining structural policies while introducing a more humanitarian face.
supporting_quotes: I was minister of education during those days -- has a tremendous challenge. How are we going to explain that there are some structural policies that have to be maintained? But at the same time we have to take care that the more humanitarian face is introduced.

events.description: Attended a congress of the Socialist Party in Bordeaux, discussing actions against Pinochet.
supporting_quotes: I remember going to a congress of the Socialist Party in Bordeaux, a congress of those Socialists living abroad. They wanted to be together in Bordeaux to discuss what can we do with Mr. Pinochet and so on and so forth. So I went to Bordeaux.

events.description: Implemented economic policies to open Chile's economy, reducing textile workers from 170,000 to 30,000 and preparing the country for global economic changes.
supporting_quotes: policy in Chile to open the economy. We used to have 170,000 textile workers, and you open the economy, and now you can import textiles from all over the world. Our industry came down from 170,000 to 30,000.
So I would say that the legacy of Pinochet was that through the changes in economic policies, Chile was able to be prepared for a world that is going to be much more open.

events.description: Responsible for providing water in rural communities, including poor rural areas, with a program costing around $2,000 to $5,000 per family.
supporting_quotes: I was minister of public works, and as such I had to provide water in rural communities.

events.description: Responsible for building highways in Chile, utilizing private funding through tolls to raise approximately US$6 billion for infrastructure development.
supporting_quotes: As the minister of public works, I had a tremendous challenge trying to build highways in Chile, and I discovered with the public money it was impossible to do, so I defined what kind of highways I wanted -- the design for a speed of so many miles per hour, etc.
I built a business in Chile [to raise money for the highways and got] about US$6 billion.

events.organization: Economic Commission for Latin America (ECLA), United Nations
events.description: Worked with Fernando Henrique Cardoso on various areas during Cardoso's exile in Chile.
supporting_quotes: Cardoso came to Chile as a political exile from Brazil, and he was working at the Economic Commission for Latin America [ECLA] in the United Nations, and we used to work together in quite a number of areas.
What can I do as a president of a small country with an open economy?

events.description: Ricardo Lagos discusses Chile's economic situation and the need for global rules in a new globalized world.
supporting_quotes: We try to do our task, and I think that Chile has been doing our task, and we have our economy in order.
